dt: {bc}to draw together or cause to converge {bc}{sx|consolidate||}
{bc}to diminish in size, amount, extent, or number
{bc}to decrease the volume and concentrate the flavor of by boiling

dt.t: add the wine and {wi}reduce{/wi} the sauce for two minutes
peoples who were {it}reduced{/it} to small reservations

dt: {bc}to bring to a specified state or condition

dt.t: the impact of the movie {it}reduced{/it} them to tears

dt: {bc}to bring to a systematic form or character
{bc}to put down in written or printed form
{bc}to correct (a fracture) by bringing displaced or broken parts back into their normal positions
{bc}to change the denominations or form of without changing the value
{bc}to construct a geometrical figure similar to but smaller than (a given figure)
{bc}to transpose from one form into another {bc}{sx|convert||}
{bc}to change (an expression) to an equivalent but more fundamental expression
{bc}to break down (as by crushing or grinding) {bc}{sx|pulverize||}
{bc}to bring to the metallic state by removal of nonmetallic elements
{bc}to combine with or subject to the action of hydrogen
{bc}to change (an element or ion) from a higher to a lower oxidation state
{bc}to add one or more electrons to (an atom or ion or molecule)
{bc}to change (a stressed vowel) to an unstressed vowel

pt: {sc}decrease{/sc} {sc}lessen{/sc} {sc}diminish{/sc} {sc}reduce{/sc} {sc}abate{/sc} {sc}dwindle{/sc} mean to grow or make less. {sc}decrease{/sc} suggests a progressive decline in size, amount, numbers, or intensity.
{sc}lessen{/sc} suggests a decline in amount rather than in number.

pt.t: has been unable to {it}lessen{/it} her debt

pt: {sc}diminish{/sc} emphasizes a perceptible loss and implies its subtraction from a total.
{sc}reduce{/sc} implies a bringing down or lowering.
{sc}abate{/sc} implies a reducing of something excessive or oppressive in force or amount.
{sc}dwindle{/sc} implies progressive lessening and is applied to things growing visibly smaller.

{sc}conquer{/sc} {sc}vanquish{/sc} {sc}defeat{/sc} {sc}subdue{/sc} {sc}reduce{/sc} {sc}overcome{/sc} {sc}overthrow{/sc} mean to get the better of by force or strategy. {sc}conquer{/sc} implies gaining mastery of.

pt.t: {it}vanquished{/it} the enemy and ended the war

pt: {sc}defeat{/sc} does not imply the finality or completeness of {sc}vanquish{/sc} which it otherwise equals.

pt.t: the Confederates {it}defeated{/it} the Union forces at Manassas
{it}subdued{/it} the native tribes after years of fighting

pt: {sc}reduce{/sc} implies a forcing to capitulate or surrender.

pt.t: the city was {it}reduced{/it} after a month-long siege

pt: {sc}overcome{/sc} suggests getting the better of with difficulty or after hard struggle.
{sc}overthrow{/sc} stresses the bringing down or destruction of existing power.

et: Middle English, to lead back, from Latin {it}reducere{/it}, from {it}re-{/it} + {it}ducere{/it} to lead {ma}{mat|tow:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to draw together or cause to converge : consolidate
to diminish in size, amount, extent, or number
to decrease the volume and concentrate the flavor of by boiling
